Federated Learning with Nesterov Accelerated Gradient

ZhengjieÂ Yang, WeiÂ Bao, DongÂ Yuan, NguyenÂ H.Â Tran, andÂ AlbertÂ Y.Â Zomaya
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a fast-developing technique that allows multiple workers to train a global model based on a distributed dataset. Conventional FL (FedAvg) employs gradient descent algorithm, which may not be efficient enough. Momentum is able to improve the situation by adding an additional momentum step to accelerate the convergence and has demonstrated its benefits in both centralized and FL environments. It is well-known that Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) is a more advantageous form of momentum, but it is not clear how to quantify the benefits of NAG in FL so far. This motives us to propose FedNAG, which employs NAG in each worker as well as NAG momentum and model aggregation in the aggregator. We provide a detailed convergence analysis of FedNAG and compare it with FedAvg. Extensive experiments based on real-world datasets and trace-driven simulation are conducted, demonstrating that FedNAG increases the learning accuracy by 3â€“24% and decreases the total training time by 11â€“70% compared with the benchmarks under a wide range of settings.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Edge computing, Nesterov accelerated gradient.

1 Introduction

With the advancement of Internet of Things (IoT), Industry 4.0, and Artificial Intelligence, machine learning applications such as image classificationÂ [1], automatic drivingÂ [2], and Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR)Â [3] are rapidly developed. Since the tremendous machine learning data are distributed in individual users, conventional centralized machine learning is insufficient when a large volume and sensitive data are required to be uploaded to remote data-centers. Moreover, in many situations, the individual users are not willing to share their sensitive raw data so it is infeasible to implement centralized machine learning. To address the issue, Federated Learning (FL) emerges [4]. It allows individual users to participate in the global model training without sharing their raw data.

Mobile Edge Computing (MEC), as shown in Fig.Â 1, is a perfect venue to implement FLÂ [5], where multiple edge devices are distributed and connected to an edge server. Workers can be any form of edge devices such as laptop, smartphone, tablet, IoT devices, etc. The edge server can aggregate the local models from edge workers and re-distribute the global model back to edge workers. Since edge workers have limited computation and communication capacities, we need to develop more efficient algorithms to accelerate the convergence and finally decrease the communication and computing workload and total training time.

One commonly adopted FL algorithm is FedAvg [4], which performs gradient descent [6] at each worker: Each worker locally updates its weights by gradient descent for a number of local iterations by its local dataset, and then the aggregator averages the weights from all workers and distribute them to the workers again. The above process is repeated for multiple rounds. (One round consists of a number of local iterations and one communication step between workers and the aggregator.) However, one disadvantage of gradient descent is its low efficiency for convergence and potential in oscillations [7, 6]. The weight update at the specific iteration tğ‘¡t is only governed by the current gradient at this iteration. It does not consider the past weight update steps. MomentumÂ [8] is able to improve the situation by adding an additional momentum step to include the difference between past and current weights on the basis of gradient descent step. The advantage of momentum has been well studied in centralized setting[9, 10, 11]. It also motivates researchers to employ momentum in FL environment [12, 13, 14]. Depending on where the momentum is adopted, these works can be categorized as aggregator momentum and worker momentum. The aggregator momentum applies momentum at the aggregator but it can only utilize the momentum acceleration every Ï„ğœ\tau local iterations when global aggregation happens. (Ï„ğœ\tau is the number of local iterations between two global aggregations.) Worker momentum utilizes the momentum acceleration at the worker but is influenced by out-of-date momentum since the momentum is only updated when global aggregation occurs and each worker does not update it in each local iteration.

Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) [15] is known to be an advantageous form of momentumÂ [8]. Existing works have demonstrated the advantage of momentum in both centralized and FL environment, but it is not clear how to quantify the benefits of NAG in FL in the literature. This motives us to propose an NAG style FL, namely FedNAG: (1) Each worker locally updates its weights and momenta using NAG for Ï„ğœ\tau iterations on its local dataset; (2) the aggregator collects and averages the weights and momenta from all workers and distribute them to the workers again; (1) and (2) are repeated for multiple rounds until the training loss is sufficiently small.

We theoretically provide a detailed convergence analysis for FedNAG. The progress mainly includes three steps: (1) We define virtual update as if centralized NAG is conducted between two global aggregations; (2) We bound the gap of weights ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} between FedNAG update and virtual update; and (3) We bound the values of global loss functions Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°F(\mathbf{w}) between FedNAG and the optimal solution. Since the convergence analysis of FedAvg is provided inÂ [16], we compare the convergence performance of FedNAG and FedAvg and derive the conditions that FedNAG outperforms FedAvg.

Experimentally, we use different models such as linear regression, logistic regression, CNN, and DNN based on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets, to test the performance of FedNAG. We analyze the impact of different factors such as number of workers, number of local updates between two global aggregataion Ï„ğœ\tau, and momentum coefficient. We also conduct a trace-driven simulation to emulate a MEC environment to test the real-world total training time consisting of computation delay and communication delay. The experiment shows that FedNAG increases the learning accuracy by 3â€“24% and decreases the total training time by 11â€“70% compared with FedMomÂ [12] and FedAvg under a wide range of settings.

2 Related works

2.1 Federated Learning Algorithms and Applications

Federated Learning was first proposed in FedAvg [4]. It allows multiple clients to collaboratively train a global learned model without sharing their raw data. Apart from FedAvg, there are many algorithms/strategies that have been studied in FL (e.g., proximityÂ [17], quantizationÂ [19], differential privacyÂ [26], Vehicular FLÂ [25] etc.). The idea of proximity is to apply an additional term on the basis of gradient descent by using the information of the global model to correct the local update. FedProxÂ [17] employs the proximal term to restrict the local updates to be closer to the global model. SCAFFOLDÂ [18] employs the control variate to prevent â€œclient-driftâ€ [18]. The idea of the quantization technique is to reduce the size of transmission payload so as to reduce the communication overhead. FedPAQÂ [19] employs quantization operators on the transmitted massages while ACGDÂ [20] employs gradient compression for communication. For Secure FL, NbAFLÂ [21] and [22] apply the Differential Privacy (DP)Â [26] in FL environment to protect the information leakage of the original raw data. In [23], authors proposes an adaptive framework consisting of blockchainÂ [27] and Reinforcement Learning (RL)Â [28] in FL to achieve higher trust and security. For Vehicular FL, FVCÂ [24] and FVNÂ [25] extend the traditional vehicular network [25] to the FL environment, where the vehicular network consists of groups of moving or stationary vehicles connected by a wireless network. However, these sub-topics are not the focus in this paper. We focus on momentumÂ [6]. The mainstream FL sub-topics are summarized in Table I.

2.2 Momentum in Machine Learning

Momentum is a method that helps accelerate gradient descent in the relevant direction by adding a fraction Î³ğ›¾\gamma of the difference between past and current model vectors [6]. There are two typical forms of momentum in the literatureÂ [29, 6]. One is Polyakâ€™s momentum [8] and the update rule is as follows:

ğ¯â€‹(t)ğ¯ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbf{v}(t) =Î³â€‹ğ¯â€‹(tâˆ’1)âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°â€‹(tâˆ’1)),absentğ›¾ğ¯ğ‘¡1ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°ğ‘¡1\displaystyle=\gamma\mathbf{v}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}(t-1)), (1)
ğ°â€‹(t)ğ°ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbf{w}(t) =ğ°â€‹(tâˆ’1)+ğ¯â€‹(t),absentğ°ğ‘¡1ğ¯ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathbf{w}(t-1)+\mathbf{v}(t), (2)

with Î³âˆˆ[0,1),t=1,2,3â€‹â€¦,ğ¯â€‹(0)=0formulae-sequenceğ›¾01formulae-sequenceğ‘¡123â€¦ğ¯00\gamma\in[0,1),t=1,2,3...,\mathbf{v}(0)=0, where Î³ğ›¾\gamma is momentum factor (weight of momentum), tğ‘¡t is update iteration, ğ¯â€‹(t)ğ¯ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}(t) is momentum term at iteration tğ‘¡t, and ğ°â€‹(t)ğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}(t) is model parameter at iteration tğ‘¡t. Through this method, the momentum term increases for dimensions whose gradients point in the same directions and reduces updates for dimensions whose gradients change directions. As a result, we gain faster convergence and reduced oscillation [6, 7]. Another typical form of momentum is Nesterov Accelerate Gradient (NAG) [15] and known as a more advantageous version of momentum compared with Polyakâ€™s momentum [8]. NAG calculates the gradient based on an approximation of the next position of parameters, i.e., âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°â€‹(tâˆ’1)+Î³â€‹ğ¯â€‹(tâˆ’1))âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°ğ‘¡1ğ›¾ğ¯ğ‘¡1\nabla F(\mathbf{w}(t-1)+\gamma\mathbf{v}(t-1)), instead of âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°â€‹(tâˆ’1))âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°ğ‘¡1\nabla F(\mathbf{w}(t-1)) in Polyakâ€™s momentum, leading to better convergence performance. This leads us to employ NAG instead of Polyakâ€™s momentum in our proposed FedNAG.

2.3 Momentum in Federated Learning

Momentum has been already well studied and proved to be more advantageous in centralized machine learning. In [9], authors study the utilization of momentum in over-parameterized models. [10] provides an unified convergence analysis for both Polyakâ€™s momentum and NAG. [11] studies NAG in stochastic settings. It also attracts researchersâ€™ attention to apply momentum in FL environment. FedMom [12] and SlowMo [13] perform momentum update in the aggregator only. In Mime [14], the aggregator computes the momentum and distributes it to the workers, which is then used by workers for local iterations. All these works also demonstrate the benefits of momentum in FL, but with more simplified approach compared with FedNAG. It is well-known that Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) [15] is a more advantageous form of momentum, but it is still not clear how to quantify the benefits of NAG in FL in the literature. This motives us to implement NAG in FL. In FedNAG, each worker computes its own momentum individually in each local iteration. The worker momenta will be also aggregated by the aggregator and re-distributed to workers. It brings substantial challenges in convergence analysis as well as better performance. This is a key issue to be addressed by this paper. A detailed comparison of different momentum-based FL algorithms is shown in TableÂ II. We also list important notations in TableÂ III.

3.3 Preliminary Analysis

We present some simple preliminary analyses, which will be used in the rest of the paper.

3.3.1 Property of Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°F(\mathbf{w})

First, according to the assumptions, it is straightforward to show that Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°F(\mathbf{w}) is convex, ÏğœŒ\rho-Lipschitz and Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth by applying triangle inequalities.

3.3.2 Divergence of Gradient

The divergence of gradient, which is commonly adopted in convergence analysisÂ [16, 31, 32] can be defined as follows.

Definition 1.

(Gradient Divergence) For âˆ€ifor-allğ‘–\forall i and âˆ€ğ°for-allğ°\forall\mathbf{w}, we define Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i} as the upper bound between âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ°\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}) and âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°\nabla F(\mathbf{w}), i.e.,

We also define

Î´â‰œâˆ‘iDiâ€‹Î´iD.â‰œğ›¿subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ·\displaystyle\delta\triangleq\frac{\sum_{i}D_{i}\delta_{i}}{D}. (10)

Please note that Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i} is different at different workers, indicating the datasets at different workers may not be independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d.) [16].

â‘£ Tradeoff between communication and convergence. Based on the Observations â‘¡ and â‘¢ above, Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1 gives the best convergence performance. However, by doing so, it will increase the communication frequency. This will lead to a tradeoff between communication overhead and convergence performance. In this paper, we do not model the costs and utilities of communication overhead (in different types of distributed systems) and convergence performance, so that the optimal tradeoff is left for future work.

â‘¤ Effect of Î´ğ›¿\delta. Following the Observation â‘¥ of Theorem 1, the convergence upper bound will be increased when Î´ğ›¿\delta is getting larger.

5 Comparison between FedAvg and FedNAG

In this section, we compare the performance between FedAvg and FedNAG. The convergence upper bound of FedAvg has been derived in Theorem 2 in [16] as follows:

Fâ€‹(ğ°^f)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)ğ¹superscript^ğ°fğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle F\left(\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{\mathrm{f}}\right)-F\left(\mathbf{w}^{*}\right)

where

h^â€‹(Ï„)^â„ğœ\displaystyle\hat{h}(\tau) =Î´Î²â€‹((Î·â€‹Î²+1)Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ’Î·â€‹Î´â€‹Ï„,absentğ›¿ğ›½superscriptğœ‚ğ›½1ğœ1ğœ‚ğ›¿ğœ\displaystyle=\frac{\delta}{\beta}\left((\eta\beta+1)^{\tau}-1\right)-\eta\delta\tau, (21)
Î±^^ğ›¼\displaystyle\hat{\alpha} â‰œÎ·â€‹(1âˆ’Î²â€‹Î·2).â‰œabsentğœ‚1ğ›½ğœ‚2\displaystyle\triangleq\eta\left(1-\frac{\beta\eta}{2}\right).

Please note that Ï,Î²,Ï„,Ï‰ğœŒğ›½ğœğœ”\rho,\beta,\tau,\omega, and Î·ğœ‚\eta are defined the same way as those in FedNAG in this paper. Î±^^ğ›¼\hat{\alpha} and h^â€‹(â‹…)^â„â‹…\hat{h}(\cdot) are defined differently, but with similar meanings as Î±ğ›¼\alpha and hâ€‹(â‹…)â„â‹…h(\cdot) in this paper.

Although FedNAG has the same convergence rate as FedAvg, we can still compare the convergence performance by comparing the convergence upper bound for a given Tğ‘‡T. In order to make a fair comparison, we let FedAvg and FedNAG trained under the same environment using the same configuration. Here, we note that Î´ğ›¿\delta and Ï‰ğœ”\omega reflect the properties of data distribution. We assume the dataset is distributed in each worker in the same way in FedAvg and FedNAG, so that the values of Ï‰ğœ”\omega and Î´ğ›¿\delta are same. The loss function Fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–â‹…F_{i}(\cdot), Fâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¹â‹…F(\cdot), constants ÏğœŒ\rho and Î²ğ›½\beta, and hyper-parameters Ï„ğœ\tau and Î·ğœ‚\eta are the same. We also set the same initial value for ğ°fsuperscriptğ°f\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}}, ğ°iâ€‹(0)subscriptğ°ğ‘–0\mathbf{w}_{i}(0) for FedAvg and FedNAG. The only new term in FedNAG is ğ¯iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ¯ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}_{i}(t), and we set ğ¯iâ€‹(0)=ğŸsubscriptğ¯ğ‘–00\mathbf{v}_{i}(0)=\mathbf{0}.

We use f1â€‹(T)subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘‡f_{1}(T) and f2â€‹(T)subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘‡f_{2}(T) to define the convergence upper bound of FedNAG and FedAvg respectively. Small function value implies better convergence performance.

f1â€‹(T)subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘‡\displaystyle f_{1}(T) â‰œ12â€‹Tâ€‹Ï‰â€‹Î±+14â€‹T2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î±2+Ïâ€‹hâ€‹(Ï„)Ï‰â€‹Î±â€‹Ï„+Ïâ€‹hâ€‹(Ï„),â‰œabsent12ğ‘‡ğœ”ğ›¼14superscriptğ‘‡2superscriptğœ”2superscriptğ›¼2ğœŒâ„ğœğœ”ğ›¼ğœğœŒâ„ğœ\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4T^{2}\omega^{2}\alpha^{2}}+\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}}+\rho h(\tau), (22)
f2â€‹(T)subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘‡\displaystyle f_{2}(T) â‰œ12â€‹Tâ€‹Ï‰â€‹Î±^+14â€‹T2â€‹Ï‰2â€‹Î±^2+Ïâ€‹h^â€‹(Ï„)Ï‰â€‹Î±^â€‹Ï„+Ïâ€‹h^â€‹(Ï„).â‰œabsent12ğ‘‡ğœ”^ğ›¼14superscriptğ‘‡2superscriptğœ”2superscript^ğ›¼2ğœŒ^â„ğœğœ”^ğ›¼ğœğœŒ^â„ğœ\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{1}{2T\omega\hat{\alpha}}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4T^{2}\omega^{2}\hat{\alpha}^{2}}+\frac{\rho\hat{h}(\tau)}{\omega\hat{\alpha}\tau}}+\rho\hat{h}(\tau). (23)

To prevent the gradient descent from overshooting the minimum or failing to converge [36], we choose a sufficiently small Î·ğœ‚\eta to guarantee the convergence of FedNAG and FedAvg. The following conclusion is made when Î·â†’0+â†’ğœ‚superscript0\eta\to 0^{+}.

Theorem 4.

When 0<Î²â€‹Î·â€‹(Î³+1)â‰¤10ğ›½ğœ‚ğ›¾110<\beta\eta(\gamma+1)\leq 1 and 0<Î³<10ğ›¾10<\gamma<1, FedNAG outperforms FedAvg, i.e.,

f1â€‹(T)<f2â€‹(T)subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘‡\displaystyle f_{1}(T)<f_{2}(T)

for any Tğ‘‡T and an arbitrarily small Î·â†’0+â†’ğœ‚superscript0\eta\to 0^{+}.

Proof.

See Appendix for detailed discussion. âˆ

Please note that we have the following observations on Theorem 4.

â‘  Discussion of Î·ğœ‚\eta. In Theorem 4, we set Î·â†’0+â†’ğœ‚superscript0\eta\to 0^{+}. Actually, there exists a threshold value for Î·ğœ‚\eta called Î·Â¯Â¯ğœ‚\bar{\eta}. If Î·<Î·Â¯ğœ‚Â¯ğœ‚\eta<\bar{\eta}, 0<Î²â€‹Î·â€‹(Î³+1)â‰¤10ğ›½ğœ‚ğ›¾110<\beta\eta(\gamma+1)\leq 1, and 0<Î³<10ğ›¾10<\gamma<1, then f1â€‹(T)<f2â€‹(T)subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘‡f_{1}(T)<f_{2}(T) is still true. Numerical method can be used to calculate the value of Î·Â¯Â¯ğœ‚\bar{\eta}.

6 Experiments

In this section we evaluate the convergence performance of FedNAG compared with benchmark algorithms including FedAvg, FedMom, centralized SGD (cSGD), and centralized NAG (cNAG) by real-world experiments. We then discuss the impacts of hyper-parameters, including global aggregation frequency Ï„ğœ\tau, momentum coefficient Î³ğ›¾\gamma, and number of workers Nğ‘N. Then, we explicitly generate different levels of non-i.i.d. data to test the performance of FedNAG and benchmarks. Finally, we perform trace-driven simulation as a digital representation of the mobile edge computing environment to analyze the total training time (including computation delay and communication delay).

6.1 Experimental Setup

In order to evaluate the convergence performance of FedNAG, we employ three real-world datasets including MNIST, CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 for image classification. MNIST [37] contains gray-scale handwritten digits of images with 28 Ã—\times 28 pixel. There are 60,000 images for training and 10,000 images for testing. CIFAR-10 [38] contains 60,000 32x32 colour images in 10 classes, with 6000 images per class while CIFAR-100 [38] contains 60,000 color images in 100 classes with 600 images per class. Both CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 contain 50,000 images for training and 10,000 images for testing. In our experiment, all samples are randomly distributed in each worker. It means that the data is i.i.d. distributed among workers. We will further consider the effects of non-i.i.d. data in Section 6.3. We implement FedNAG and other benchmarks using PySyft library [39] based on the PyTorch framework. PySyft can emulate various virtual workers to process federated learning jobs. The training process is run on a GPU tower server with 4 NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080Ti GPUs.

We use four models including linear regression model, logistic regression model, CNN model and DNN model. Linear regression uses mean squared error loss, and logistic regression uses cross-entropy loss. The CNN modelâ€™s structure is similar to the classic one in [40], which has two 5Ã—5555\times 5 convolutional layers with 32 and 64 channels respectively. In each convolutional layer, 2Ã—2222\times 2 max pooling is used. The last two following layers are ReLu activation and softmax. DNN model is VGG16. We use mini-batch in all experiments, and the batch size is 64. We set the default learning step size Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01. Other experimental settings are listed in Table Â IV.

6.2 Performance Evaluation

6.2.1 Convergence Performance

In Fig.Â 3, we compare the convergence performance of FedNAG with other four benchmark algorithms. The experiment is performed on three datasets. MNIST is trained by linear regression, logistic regression and CNN; CIFAR-10 is trained by CNN and DNN (VGG16), and CIFAR-100 is trained by DNN (VGG16). For convex model, we set Ï„=20,Î³=0.9,N=4formulae-sequenceğœ20formulae-sequenceğ›¾0.9ğ‘4\tau=20,\gamma=0.9,N=4. For non-convex model, we set Ï„=40,Î³=0.9,N=4formulae-sequenceğœ40formulae-sequenceğ›¾0.9ğ‘4\tau=40,\gamma=0.9,N=4. For MNIST, the total number of iterations Tğ‘‡T is 1000. For CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, Tğ‘‡T is set to 10000.

Figs.Â 3(a), 3(b), 3(c), 3(d), 3(e), and 3(f) show the values of the global loss function and accuracy trained under different models and datasets respectively. As a result, for convex models, we have cNAG >> FedNAG >> cSGD >> FedMom >> FedAvg. For non-convex models, we have cNAG >> FedNAG >> FedMom >> cSGD >> FedAvg. (We use â€œ>>â€ to indicate â€œis better thanâ€ for convenient presentation.) For centralized approaches, we can see cNAG performs better than cSGD in all cases. For distributed approaches, FedNAG also performs better than FedAvg and FedMom. It confirms that NAG is more advantageous compared with gradient decent for both centralized and FL environment. For cNAG and FedNAG, we can find FedNAG performs worse. This follows our expectation shown in Theorem 3. FedNAG performs Ï„ğœ\tau local updates before a global aggregation, causing less efficient updates and thus decreases the convergence performance. For FedNAG and FedMom, we can find FedNAG performs better than FedMom in all cases. For convex models, the gap between FedNAG and FedMom is significant. For non-convex models, FedNAG still performs better than FedMom. It confirms that FedNAG can accelerate the convergence performance for both convex and non-convex tasks, while FedMom only works well for non-convex tasks.

Another interesting observation is that FedNAG can perform better than cSGD in all cases: The benefits of the momentum method can outweigh the performance loss by federated learning.

6.2.2 Effects of Global Aggregation Frequency Ï„ğœ\tau

In Fig.Â 4(a), we evaluate the impact of Ï„ğœ\tau based on global loss and accuracy using the same CNN model and MNIST dataset. The setting for this experiment is Î³=0.5,T=1000,N=4formulae-sequenceğ›¾0.5formulae-sequenceğ‘‡1000ğ‘4\gamma=0.5,T=1000,N=4.

From Fig.Â 4(a), we can observe when Ï„ğœ\tau is increased, the convergence performance is reduced. When it converges, loss is larger and accuracy is lower. This matches â‘  of Theorem 3. The convergence upper bound increases with Ï„ğœ\tau. In Fig.Â 4(b), we observe the impact of Ï„ğœ\tau in a wider range [5,640]5640[5,640]. In Fig.Â 4(b) (left), we plot the number of iterations when the global loss reaches the target value 0.5. In Fig.Â 4(b) (right), we plot the number of iterations when the accuracy reaches the target value 85%. Since the global loss and accuracy may oscillate during the training process, the target global loss and accuracy may be reached several times. The red horizontal lines indicate the first and last iterations when the target values are reached, and the bar indicates the mean of the iterations when the targets are reached.

The outcome also shows that given a targeted loss or accuracy, the number of iterations does not monotonically increase or decrease with Ï„ğœ\tau. There is an optimal value Ï„ğœ\tau. This is because smaller Ï„ğœ\tau leads to slower descent at the beginning (Fig.Â 4(a) in the main paper), but it converges closer to the optimal value in the end. The two effects cancel with each other and Ï„=40ğœ40\tau=40 performs the best in our setting in Fig.Â 4(b).

The similar phenomenon also appears in other FL algorithmsÂ [13, 16]. Moreover, If we double Ï„ğœ\tau when Ï„ğœ\tau is small, the number of iterations to reach the targets does not change much. However, if we double Ï„ğœ\tau when Ï„ğœ\tau is too large (e.g., Ï„â‰¥80ğœ80\tau\geq 80), then the number of iterations to reach the targets substantially increases. This matches â‘¤ of Theorem 1, which concludes that larger Ï„ğœ\tau leads to exponential increase of hâ€‹(â‹…)â„â‹…h(\cdot). Therefore, increasing Ï„ğœ\tau will significantly delay the training process when Ï„ğœ\tau is too large.

6.2.3 Effects of Momentum Coefficient Î³ğ›¾\gamma

In Fig.Â 4(c), we evaluate the effects of Î³ğ›¾\gamma. The setting for this experiment is Ï„=4,T=1000,N=4formulae-sequenceğœ4formulae-sequenceğ‘‡1000ğ‘4\tau=4,T=1000,N=4. We also use the same CNN model trained on the same MNIST dataset.

Fig.Â 4(c) shows the global loss and accuracy under Î³=0.1,0.3,0.6,0.9ğ›¾0.10.30.60.9\gamma=0.1,0.3,0.6,0.9 respectively. It shows that Î³ğ›¾\gamma can increase the convergence performance (smaller global loss value and higher accuracy). For Fig.Â 4(d), we evaluate the global loss at T=500ğ‘‡500T=500 and T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000 respectively, when Î³ğ›¾\gamma ranges from [0,0.99]00.99[0,0.99]. Two horizontal lines are the benchmarks where only FedAvg is used. For both T=500ğ‘‡500T=500 and T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000, we can see the global loss decreases when Î³ğ›¾\gamma is getting large. Accuracy is also increased at the same time. However, from Fig.Â 4(e), when Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1, the global loss cannot converge due to the prerequisite where 0<Î³<10ğ›¾10<\gamma<1 [6].

6.2.4 Effects of Number of Workers Nğ‘N

In Fig.Â 4(f), we evaluate the global loss and accuracy based on different number of workers Nğ‘N using the same CNN model and MNIST dataset. The experiment setting is Ï„=4,Î³=0.9,T=1000formulae-sequenceğœ4formulae-sequenceğ›¾0.9ğ‘‡1000\tau=4,\gamma=0.9,T=1000. From Fig.Â 4(f), we can see that increasing Nğ‘N will cause a decline of convergence performance. This follows our expectation because more workers cause more divergence among the workers and thus decrease convergence performance. However, after a sufficient number of iterations, the global loss and accuracy with more workers will be closer to those with fewer workers. It shows that FedNAG is applicable when there are more workers in the system.

6.3 Effects of non-i.i.d. data distribution

In Fig.Â 5, we evaluate the effects of different levels of non-i.i.d. data distribution. We train CNN on MNIST with the setting Ï„=40,Î³=0.9,N=4,T=1000formulae-sequenceğœ40formulae-sequenceğ›¾0.9formulae-sequenceğ‘4ğ‘‡1000\tau=40,\gamma=0.9,N=4,T=1000. The curves show the training accuracy. To quantify the level of non-i.i.d. data distribution, we explicitly assign only x<10ğ‘¥10x<10 out of 10 classes of data for each worker. (Each worker has data samples from a subset of classes.) Smaller x represents higher level of non-i.i.d. setting. We use 3-class non-i.i.d., 6-class non-i.i.d., and 9-class non-i.i.d. to represent high, middle and low level of non-i.i.d. data respectively.

In all cases, We can observe FedNAG >> FedMom >> FedAvg. This shows that FedNAG outperforms benchmarks under any levels of non-i.i.d. data distribution. We also observe higher level of non-i.i.d. setting decreases convergence performance for all algorithms. Specifically, FedNAG achieves 58.87% accuracy for high level non-i.i.d. data, while achieving 87.90% accuracy and 97.28% accuracy for middle and low level non-i.i.d. data respectively. This matches our expectations in Observation â‘¥ in Theorem 1 where higher level of non-i.i.d. setting causes more data divergence that is denoted by larger Î´ğ›¿\delta, and therefore lowers the accuracy.

6.4 Trace-Driven Simulation

We emulate the real-world edge-computing environment and compare the total training time with an expected learning accuracy (0.95) on FedNAG and other benchmarks when CNN in trained on MNIST. We train the model in the GPU tower server and keep the trace of the sequence of iterations. We then use real-world devices as workers (one laptop with Intel Core i3 M380 CPU, three Android phones: Nubia z17s with Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 CPU, Realme GT Neo with MTK Dimensity 1200 CPU, Redmi K30 Ultra with MTK Dimensity 1000+ CPU) to sample worker computing delays. The aggregator computing delay is sampled on GPU tower server. All devices are connected to HUAWEI honor router X2+ with 5GHz WIFI to sample communication delays which depend on the communication workload of transmitting the models/momenta. We use the trace of the sequence of iterations and the sampled delays to figure out the overall training time as if the training process is conducted by the GPU server (aggregator) and the four devices.

Please note such approach to use a digital representation of physical objects to conduct experiment is widely used in distributed systems, IoT, and machine learning applications [41, 42]. It can generate the convincing system performance evaluation without deploying physical devices.

In Fig.Â 6, we observe that under two different settings (Ï„=40ğœ40\tau=40 or Ï„=20ğœ20\tau=20, N=4ğ‘4N=4), to reach the accuracy 0.95, FedNAG spends 263.34s (Ï„=40ğœ40\tau=40) and 307.35s (Ï„=20ğœ20\tau=20) while FedMom spends 377.20s (Ï„=40ğœ40\tau=40) and 345.72s (Ï„=20ğœ20\tau=20), and FedAvg spends 893.96s (Ï„=40ğœ40\tau=40) and 1011.72s (Ï„=20ğœ20\tau=20). This demonstrates that FedNAG is efficient and decreases the total training time by 11â€“70% compared with FedMom and FedAvg.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we focus on FedNAG, a NAG style momentum-based FL algorithm. FedNAG allows each worker to update its weights and momenta by its local dataset for a number of local iterations between two global aggregations. On the global aggregation step, the aggregator collects and averages the weights and momenta from all workers and distributes them to the workers. The convergence analysis shows the upper bound of the gap between the global loss function derived by FedNAG at iteration Tğ‘‡T and the optimal solution. We compare FedNAG and FedAvg, and conclude that as long as the learning step size is sufficiently small, FedNAG outperforms FedAvg. Experiments based on real-world datasets and trace-driven simulation are conducted, demonstrating that FedNAG increases the learning accuracy by 3â€“24% and decreases the total training time by 11â€“70% compared with the benchmarks.
